metadata.case_name: Jagirdar of Thikana Rakhi v. State of Rajasthan & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant was the Jagirdar of Thikana Rakhi in the Marwar Jodhpur area of the State of Rajasthan. Within Thikana Rakhi was the village of Khakharki. He had a number of tenants under him in the village who paid rent on the basis of a certain share of the produce of the land held.
Marwar Tenancy Act of 1949 was in force in the Marwar area, passed by His Highness the Maharaja of Jodhpur before integration into Rajasthan.
Section 78 of Tenancy Act: When rent payable by division of produce or estimate/appraisement of standing crop, landlord or tenant may apply to Tahsildar for division etc. if not amicably done.
Section 79 of Tenancy Act lays down procedure at hearing of s.78 application; amount found due as rent has effect of decree for arrears.
Appellant had difficulty realising rent from tenants in Khakharki; applied under s.78 to Tahsildar, Merta on October 31, 1950.

Government of Rajasthan issued Notification under s.85 of Tenancy Act on February 22, 1951, declaring rents in Khakharki (inter alia) recoverable as arrears of land revenue; published in Official Gazette on March 3, 1951.
Appellant filed application under s.85 to Collector, Nagaur on March 9, 1951, for recovery of 1950-51 rents from refusing tenants as arrears of land revenue.
Appellant's s.78 application dismissed on March 26, 1951.
Tenants filed application on March 29, 1951, in Collector Nagaur court for notice and hearing on s.85 application, as required by rules under Revenue Courts Act 1951; rejected by Collector.
Collector passed order on April 5, 1951, finding Rs. 38,587-3-0 due to appellant from tenants on account of rent, other charges and court fees; sent to Tahsildar Merta for recovery as arrears.
Tenants appealed to Additional Commissioner, Jodhpur; dismissed on November 2, 1951.
Tenants filed revision to Board of Revenue, Rajasthan; Board held Revenue Courts Act did not affect s.85 procedure but remanded for other points.
Additional Commissioner dismissed appeal again on July 7, 1952, after hearing other points.
Government of Rajasthan published notification on November 1, 1952, rescinding February 22, 1951 notification under s.85.
Tenants filed revision against July 7, 1952 order to Board of Revenue; Board rejected contentions including effect of rescission and dismissed on September 29, 1953.

43 tenants filed writ petition in Rajasthan High Court for certiorari to quash orders of Collector, Additional Commissioner, and Board; High Court allowed on April 27, 1954, quashed orders holding no further proceedings possible after cancellation of s.85 notification; granted certificate for SC appeal.
Rent found due has not been realised yet by Tahsildar due to pending proceedings.
Rajasthan Revenue Courts Procedure and Jurisdiction Act of 1951 came into force on January 31, 1951.
Revenue Courts Act repealed in 1955 after High Court judgment.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.85 of Marwar Tenancy Act, 1949 was repealed by s.2 of Rajasthan Revenue Courts Procedure and Jurisdiction Act, 1951.
Whether procedure under Revenue Courts Act (Ch. II rules requiring notice and hearing) applies to s.85 Tenancy Act applications, replacing ex parte procedure.
Whether proceedings under s.85 can continue after rescission of the notification issued under sub-s.1.
Whether the notification under s.85 was valid, given that 82 out of 125 tenants had paid rent and remaining 43 were willing but disputed amount.

respondent_arguments.text: s.85 of Tenancy Act repealed by Revenue Courts Act; no action possible after latter came into force.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2 Revenue Courts Act; long title and preamble

respondent_arguments.text: Procedure for s.85 applications governed by Ch. II rules under Revenue Courts Act (r.114), requiring notice and hearing; not followed, error apparent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: r.114 Ch.IV and Ch.II rules under Revenue Courts Act; rules under s.85 Tenancy Act repealed

respondent_arguments.text: After rescission of notification on Nov 1, 1952, no further proceedings under s.85 possible.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.85(2) Tenancy Act: 'in any local area to which a notification...applies'

respondent_arguments.text: Notification invalid as no general refusal to pay rent (82/125 paid, 43 willing but disputed quantum).

court_reasoning.text: Revenue Courts Act does not repeal s.85 as it deals only with jurisdiction/procedure, not substantive right created by s.85 to recover rent as land revenue on notification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Schedule to Revenue Courts Act recognises s.85 applications without limitation, contemplates continuance of s.85.

court_reasoning.text: s.85 contemplates ex parte hearing without notice to tenants: no provision for notice; post-notification general refusal already decided; summary proceedings like land revenue recovery; cl.(b) sub-s.4 implies no prior hearing; contested procedure would defeat purpose and duplicate ss.78/80.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Procedure integral to substantive right under s.85; Revenue Courts Act/r.114 does not override ex parte nature.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'in any local area to which a notification...applies' refer to area, not time; no time limit in s.85(2); limitation in Tenancy Act schedule repealed by Revenue Courts Act (no limitation now); power vests on valid application during notification; rescission does not divest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Application made before rescission; proceedings can continue post-rescission.

court_reasoning.text: Tenants cannot raise validity of notification now: not raised in High Court; involves facts and interpretation not agitated earlier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not open to tenants at this stage.

holdings.text: s.85 Tenancy Act not repealed by Revenue Courts Act; application to Collector post-1951 Act valid, no limitation.
s.85 applications heard ex parte without notice/hearing; Revenue Courts Act rules do not apply to override this.
Rescission of notification does not bar completion of pending s.85 proceedings if application made validly during its force.
Challenge to notification validity not entertainable at this stage.

precedents_cited.relevance: Principles for temporary Acts do not apply to s.85 activated by notification.

statutes_cited.name: Marwar Tenancy Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs rent recovery applications; s.85 allows summary recovery as land revenue post-notification; ex parte procedure inherent.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Revenue Courts Procedure and Jurisdiction Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates jurisdiction/procedure; repeals procedural parts of Tenancy Act (ss.118,124,129) but preserves s.85 substantive right; Schedule recognises s.85 applications to Collector without limitation.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the Rajasthan High Court judgment quashing the revenue authorities' orders, holding that s.85 proceedings were validly initiated and could proceed ex parte even after notification rescission; rent recovery as arrears permissible.
outcome.relief_granted: Orders of Collector, Additional Commissioner, and Board of Revenue restored; proceedings for recovery of Rs. 38,587-3-0 as arrears resume.

key_quotes.text: "Quite clearly, s. 85 creates, on the requisite notification being issued, a substantive right in a landlord to have the rent due to him recovered as arrears of land revenue."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes substantive right under s.85 from procedural provisions of Revenue Courts Act.

key_quotes.text: "It seems clear to us that s. 85 itself requires an application made under it to be heard ex parte."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on ex parte nature defeating need for notice/hearing.

key_quotes.text: "Subsequent cancellation of the notification would not divest the appropriate authority of the power already vested in him to dispose of the application which was properly and duly made under s. 85."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Resolves effect of notification rescission on pending proceedings.
